description:
Coccidioides posadasii RMSCC 3700 is a dimorphic fungus that belongs to the genus Coccidioides. It is one of the causative agents of coccidioidomycosis, a serious respiratory disease also known as Valley Fever.

C. posadasii RMSCC 3700 is a soil-dwelling organism that can exist in two forms: a mycelial, filamentous form in the environment and a spherical, endospore-producing form in the host. The spherical form, known as a spherule, can release hundreds of infectious endospores that can be inhaled by humans and animals, leading to the development of coccidioidomycosis.

This particular isolate, RMSCC 3700, was obtained from the Rocky Mountain Spotted Fever and Rickettsial Diseases Laboratory (RMSCC) and is a member of the C. posadasii species, which is genetically distinct from the closely related species, C. immitis.

C. posadasii RMSCC 3700 is an important subject of study for understanding the biology, epidemiology, and potential treatments for coccidioidomycosis, a significant public health concern in areas where the fungus is endemic, such as the southwestern United States and parts of Central and South America.
